*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion clearly affirms that custody determinations must be based on the best interests of the child and applies that standard at length. However, this case involves an initial custody determination in the context of dissolving a recognized spousal relationship, not a modification of a prior custody order. The court does not discuss or require a threshold showing of a ‘material change in circumstances’ before altering an existing custody arrangement, so it does not support that portion of the proposition, even though it is good authority for the best‑interests standard generally.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is]… what is ‘best for the child’…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge… However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The best interests of the child standard is applied in the context of the particular needs and circumstances of the child in question.” *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. at 494 (internal citations omitted).

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion does apply a ‘best interests of the child’ standard in the context of custody and international removal, but it does not articulate or apply a prerequisite of a ‘material change in circumstances’ for modifying custody or visitation. Instead, it interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30’s ‘upon cause shown’ language purely as a best‑interests standard for removal. Thus, while Yannas is strong authority for the best‑interests requirement, it does not support the separate proposition that a custody modification must be predicated on a material change in circumstances.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

*Brauer v. Brauer*, 370 Mass. 512 (1976).support_reasoning: Brauer v. Brauer is a Land Court/zoning‑restriction case about enforcement and modification of a restrictive covenant under G.L. c. 184, § 30. It does not concern family law, custody, or standards governing modification of child custody orders, nor does it mention a ‘material change in circumstances’ or ‘best interests of the child.’ Citing Brauer as authority for custody‑modification principles therefore misattributes its holding and context.
*Brauer v. Brauer*, 370 Mass. 512 (1976).relevant_excerpt: "Reaching the merits, the judge applied the several criteria of G. L. c. 184, § 30, and concluded that adequate reason had not been shown why the restriction should give way. The case taken as a whole presented a not unfamiliar problem. Had the neighborhood deteriorated or changed its character to such an extent, from the time the restriction was laid on to the time of trial, that enforcing the restriction according to its terms would be merely quixotic... Or was the neighborhood still maintaining its essential character..."

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, courts may modify an existing custody order if there is a material change in circumstances that affects the child’s welfare (*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (2006); G.L. c. 208, § 28).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is about removal/relocation under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and the applicable ‘best interests’ standard when parents share joint legal and physical custody. It does not articulate the separate, general rule that an existing custody order may be modified upon a material change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare (the standard that comes from G.L. c. 208, § 28 and other cases). The only mention of “substantial change in circumstances” appears in a quotation from the ALI Principles regarding relocation, not as a Massachusetts rule governing modification of custody orders under § 28.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:

“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] ...”

[This is an ALI principle being quoted, not a Massachusetts holding under G.L. c. 208, § 28.]

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: The deterioration of the Defendant's physical condition constitutes a **substantial and material change** in circumstances such that the current 50/50 physical custody arrangement no longer serves the child’s best interests (*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)).
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation request and the standards under Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, not a claim that a parent’s deteriorated physical condition constitutes a material and substantial change warranting a change from a 50/50 physical custody arrangement. The only discussion of “material and substantial change” is to correct the trial judge and to hold that the mother’s remarriage (not health deterioration) is a material and substantial change under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The case therefore does not establish or apply any rule that a parent’s declining physical condition justifies altering a shared custody arrangement on best‑interest grounds.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… ‘[T]he court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment… provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred….’ … In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Courts emphasize that the **best interests of the child** is the guiding standard in custody cases (G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (1983)).

*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.proposition: Courts emphasize that the **best interests of the child** is the guiding standard in custody cases (G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (1983)).
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the interaction between parental fitness and the child’s welfare, noting that the critical question is whether parents are fit to further the child’s welfare and best interests. However, in the care-and-protection/termination context it frames the controlling legal standard as parental unfitness proven by clear and convincing evidence, and expressly rejects deciding custody based on a comparative ‘better custodian’ analysis. It does not clearly state, in the way the proposition suggests, that the general guiding standard in custody disputes is simply the best interests of the child under G.L. c. 208, § 31.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.relevant_excerpt: “State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.… In that sense, the fitness of parents and the best interests of the child are related.… ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently acknowledged the importance of ensuring that custody arrangements promote the child’s physical and emotional welfare (*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Hershon v. Hershon*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 209 (1985)).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the standard governing custody determinations and emphasizes that the court’s “overriding concern” must be the children’s best interests, including their happiness and welfare, both present and future. The court repeatedly frames the custody, joint custody, and visitation analysis around promoting the children’s welfare and a healthy environment for their growth and development, which aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts recognize the importance of custody arrangements that promote children’s physical and emotional welfare.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.… ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the [children] should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the [children] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future….’ … These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

*Hershon v. Hershon*, 20 Mass. *Guardianship of Williams*, 83 Mass. App.proposition: The modification requested is consistent with the principle that children should not be placed in caregiving roles for their parents, an arrangement courts have deemed inappropriate (*Guardianship of Williams*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 135 (2013)).
*Guardianship of Williams*, 83 Mass. App.support_reasoning: Nothing in this opinion concerns family law, guardianship, children, or caregiving roles for parents. The case is about judicial review of inmate grievance procedures and applicable statutes of limitation for such appeals. It does not establish or discuss any principle that children should not be placed in caregiving roles for their parents, so citing it for that proposition is inaccurate.
*Guardianship of Williams*, 83 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: “The central question in this case is whether G. L. c. 127, § 38H, requires judicial review of inmate grievances pursuant to G. L. c. 30A, § 14, or whether, despite the explicit language of G. L. c. 127, § 38H, such appeals must be brought pursuant to G. L. c. 249, § 4.”

*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (197.support_reasoning: The opinion in Gilmore v. Gilmore concerns procedural rights in custody proceedings, specifically the right to cross‑examine a guardian ad litem whose report the judge relies on. The court reiterates that the governing principle in custody cases is the best interests of the child, but it does not discuss or decide that failure to modify a custody order would place a child in a developmentally harmful or unsafe position. The case is thus about evidentiary fairness and appellate/procedural issues, not about standards for modifying custody based on developmental harm or safety risks.
*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (197.relevant_excerpt: “We are mindful of the court’s need for assistance in arriving at a just resolution of custody cases. There is no question that court-appointed investigators can help a judge to determine what is in the best interests of a child, ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided.’ Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930). … In order to determine adequately the reliability and accuracy of a report, we believe that, as a matter of sound judicial policy, the parties should have the opportunity to rebut the report, including the right to cross-examine the investigator.”
